abstract_sentences.1: Existing question answering methods infer answers either from a knowledge base or from raw text.
abstract_sentences.2: While knowledge base (KB) methods are good at answering compositional questions, their performance is often affected by the incompleteness of the KB.
abstract_sentences.3: Au contraire, web text contains millions of facts that are absent in the KB, however in an unstructured form.
abstract_sentences.4: Universal schema can support reasoning on the union of both structured KBs and unstructured text by aligning them in a common embedded space.
abstract_sentences.5: In this paper we extend universal schema to natural language question answering, employing memory networks to attend to the large body of facts in the combination of text and KB.
abstract_sentences.6: Our models can be trained in an end-to-end fashion on question-answer pairs.
abstract_sentences.7: Evaluation results on SPADES fill-in-the-blank question answering dataset show that exploiting universal schema for question answering is better than using either a KB or text alone.
abstract_sentences.8: This model also outperforms the current state-of-the-art by 8.5 F1 points.

https://doi.org/10.18653/v1/P17-2057  1 Introduction  Question Answering (QA) has been a longstanding goal of natural language processing.
body_sentences.2: Two main paradigms evolved in solving this problem: 1) answering questions on a knowledge base; and 2) answering questions using text.
body_sentences.3: Knowledge bases (KB) contains facts expressed in a fixed schema, facilitating compositional reasoning.
body_sentences.4: These attracted research ever since the early days of computer science, e.g., BASEBALL (Green Jr et al., 1961).
body_sentences.5:
This problem has matured into learning semantic parsers from parallel question and logical form pairs (Zelle and Mooney,
1996; Zettlemoyer and Collins, 2005), to recent scaling of methods to work on very large KBs like Freebase using question and answer pairs (Berant et al., 2013).
body_sentences.6: However, a major drawback of this paradigm is that KBs are highly incomplete (Dong et al., 2014).
body_sentences.7:
It is also an open question whether KB relational structure is expressive enough to represent world knowledge (Stanovsky et al., 2014; Gardner and Krishnamurthy, 2017)
The paradigm of exploiting text for questions started in the early 1990s (Kupiec, 1993).
body_sentences.8: With the advent of web, access to text resources became abundant and cheap.
body_sentences.9: Initiatives like TREC QA competitions helped popularizing this paradigm (Voorhees et al., 1999).
body_sentences.10: With the recent advances in deep learning and availability of large public datasets, there has been an explosion of research in a very short time (Rajpurkar et al., 2016; Trischler et al., 2016; Nguyen et al., 2016; Wang and Jiang, 2016; Lee et al., 2016; Xiong et al., 2016; Seo et al., 2016; Choi et al., 2016).
body_sentences.11: Still, text representation is unstructured and does not allow the compositional reasoning which structured KB supports.
body_sentences.12: An important but under-explored QA paradigm is where KB and text are exploited together (Ferrucci et al., 2010).
body_sentences.13: Such combination is attractive because text contains millions of facts not present in KB, and a KB’s generative capacity represents infinite number of facts that are never seen in text.
body_sentences.14: However QA inference on this combination is challenging due to the structural non-uniformity of KB and text.
body_sentences.15: Distant supervision methods (Bunescu and Mooney, 2007; Mintz et al., 2009; Riedel et al., 2010; Yao et al., 2010; Zeng et al., 2015) address this problem partially by means of aligning text patterns with KB.
body_sentences.16: But the rich and ambiguous nature of language allows a fact to be expressed in many different forms which these models fail to capture.
body_sentences.17:
Universal schema (Riedel et al., 2013) avoids the alignment problem by jointly embedding KB facts

body_sentences.18: Figure 1 shows a universal schema matrix which has pairs of entities as rows, and Freebase and textual relations in columns.
body_sentences.19: Although universal schema has been extensively used for relation extraction, this paper shows its applicability to QA.
body_sentences.20: Consider the question USA has elected blank , our first african-american president with its answer Barack Obama.
body_sentences.21: While Freebase has a predicate for representing presidents of USA, it does not have one for ‘african-american’ presidents.
body_sentences.22: Whereas in text, we find many sentences describing the presidency of Barack Obama and his ethnicity at the same time.
body_sentences.23: Exploiting both KB and text makes it relatively easy to answer this question than relying on only one of these sources.

body_sentences.26: In this work, we define the memory components as observed cells of the universal schema matrix, and train an end-to-end QA model on question-answer pairs.
body_sentences.27: The contributions of the paper are as follows (a) We show that universal schema representation is a better knowledge source for QA than either KB or text alone, (b) On the SPADES dataset (Bisk et al., 2016), containing real world fill-in-the-blank questions, we outperform state-of-the-art semantic parsing baseline, with 8.5 F1 points.
body_sentences.28: (c) Our analysis shows how individual data sources help fill the weakness of the other, thereby improving overall performance.

body_sentences.34: Universal Schema Traditionally universal schema is used for relation extraction in the context of knowledge base population.
body_sentences.35: Rows in the schema are formed by entity pairs (e.g.
body_sentences.36: USA, NYC), and columns represent the relation between them.
body_sentences.37: A relation can either be a KB relation, or it could be a pattern of text that exist between these two entities in a large corpus.
body_sentences.38: The embeddings of entities and relation types are learned by low-rank matrix factorization techniques.

body_sentences.42: Using distributed representation allows reasoning on sentences that are similar in meaning but different on the surface form.
body_sentences.43: We too use this variant to encode our textual relations.
body_sentences.44: Memory Networks MemNNs are neural attention models with external and differentiable memory.
body_sentences.45: MemNNs decouple the memory component from the network thereby allowing it store external information.

Previously, these have been successfully applied to question answering on KB where the memory is filled with distributed representation of KB triples (Bordes et al., 2015), or for read-
ing comprehension (Sukhbaatar et al., 2015; Hill et al., 2016), where the memory consists of distributed representation of sentences in the comprehension.
body_sentences.47: Recently, key-value MemNN are introduced (Miller et al., 2016) where each memory slot consists of a key and value.
body_sentences.48: The attention weight is computed only by comparing the question with the key memory, whereas the value is used to compute the contextual representation to predict the answer.
body_sentences.49: We use this variant of MemNN for our model.

body_sentences.84: 4 Experiments    4.1 Evaluation Dataset  We use Freebase (Bollacker et al., 2008) as our KB, and ClueWeb (Gabrilovich et al., 2013) as our text source to build universal schema.
body_sentences.85: For evaluation, literature offers two options: 1) datasets for text-based question answering tasks such as answer sentence selection and reading comprehension; and 2) datasets for KB question answering.
body_sentences.86: Although the text-based question answering datasets are large in size, e.g., SQuAD (Rajpurkar et al., 2016) has over 100k questions, answers to these are often not entities but rather sentences which are not the focus of our work.
body_sentences.87: Moreover these texts may not contain Freebase entities at all, making these skewed heavily towards text.
body_sentences.88: Coming to the alternative option, WebQuestions (Berant et al., 2013) is widely used for QA on Freebase.
body_sentences.89: This dataset is curated such that all questions can be answered on Freebase alone.
body_sentences.90: But since our goal is to explore the impact of universal schema, testing on a dataset completely answerable on a KB is not ideal.
body_sentences.91: WikiMovies dataset (Miller et al., 2016) also has similar properties.
body_sentences.92:
Gardner and Krishnamurthy (2017) created a dataset with motivations similar to
ours, however this is not publicly released during the submission time.
body_sentences.93: Instead, we use SPADES (Bisk et al., 2016) as our evaluation data which contains fill-in-the-blank cloze-styled questions created from ClueWeb.
body_sentences.94: This dataset is ideal to test our hypothesis for following reasons: 1) it is large with 93K sentences and 1.8M entities; and 2) since these are collected from Web, most sentences are natural.
body_sentences.95: A limitation of this dataset is that it contains only the sentences that have entities connected by at least one relation in Freebase, making it skewed towards Freebase as we will see (§ 4.4).
body_sentences.96: We use the standard train, dev and test splits for our experiments.
body_sentences.97: For text part of universal schema, we use the sentences present in the training set.
body_sentences.98: 4.2 Models  We evaluate the following models to measure the impact of different knowledge sources for QA.
body_sentences.99: ONLYKB: In this model, MemNN memory contains only the facts from KB.
body_sentences.100: For each KB triple (e1,r,e2), we have two memory slots, one for (e1,r,e2) and the other for its inverse (e2,ri,e1).
body_sentences.101: ONLYTEXT: SPADES contains sentences with blanks.
body_sentences.102: We replace the blank tokens with the answer entities to create textual facts from the training set.
body_sentences.103: Using every pair of entities, we create a memory cell similar to as in universal schema.
body_sentences.104: ENSEMBLE This is an ensemble of the above two models.
body_sentences.105: We use a linear model that combines the scores from, and use an ensemble to combine the evidences from individual models.
body_sentences.106: UNISCHEMA This is our main model with universal schema as its memory, i.e., it contains memory slots corresponding to both KB and textual facts.

body_sentences.137:
5 Related Work  A majority of the QA literature that focused on exploiting KB and text either improves the infer-
ence on the KB using text based features (Krishnamurthy and Mitchell, 2012; Reddy et al., 2014; Joshi et al., 2014; Yao and Van Durme, 2014; Yih et al., 2015; Neelakantan et al., 2015b; Guu et al., 2015; Xu et al., 2016b; Choi et al., 2015; Savenkov and Agichtein, 2016) or improves the inference on text using KB (Sun et al., 2015).
body_sentences.138: Limited work exists on exploiting text and KB jointly for question answering.
body_sentences.139: Gardner and Krishnamurthy (2017) is the closest to ours who generate a open-vocabulary logical form and rank candidate answers by how likely they occur with this logical form both in Freebase and text.
body_sentences.140: Our models are trained on a weaker supervision signal without requiring the annotation of the logical forms.
body_sentences.141: A few QA methods infer on curated databases combined with OpenIE triples (Fader et al., 2014; Yahya et al., 2016; Xu et al., 2016a).
body_sentences.142: Our work differs from them in two ways: 1) we do not need an explicit database query to retrieve the answers (Neelakantan et al., 2015a; Andreas et al., 2016); and 2) our text-based facts retain complete sentential context unlike the OpenIE triples (Banko et al., 2007; Carlson et al., 2010).
body_sentences.143: 6 Conclusions  In this work, we showed universal schema is a promising knowledge source for QA than using KB or text alone.
body_sentences.144: Our results conclude though KB is preferred over text when the KB contains the fact of interest, a large portion of queries still attend to text indicating the amalgam of both text and KB is superior than KB alone.
